Colin, yes, the idea of a powerful representation that can easily capture=
 the most important operations (such as comparison or multiplication) is al=
ways lurking in the background.  Yet trade-offs always seem to emerge when =
we try to bestow such capabilities explicitly.  For example, if we added mu=
ltiplication, it may theoretically allow certain key computations to be rep=
resented easily, yet it also gives evolution a new power to more easily des=
troy what it has built through trivial mutations (because multiplication is=
 more powerful than summation).  

I am sure that CPPNs as a representation=
al formalism can be improved, yet the presence of these nagging trade-offs =
makes me think that the idea of a super-powerful representation is a false =
ideal.  It seems to me at this point that evolution in nature succeeds desp=
ite the limited nature of its representation rather than because DNA is som=
ehow near perfect.  I doubt that any set of operators or basis functions ca=
n ever really be selected perfectly to best describe some of the complexiti=
es of high-level cognition.   Rather, evolution seems to rely on a kind of =
unrelenting persistence to drag itself higher despite the obstacle of a lim=
ited basis.  

Of course, these thoughts don't contradict anything you said=
.  The length input trick also shows that to some extent we can provide dra=
matic bias through a priori knowledge, which is a good thing (e.g. if it me=
ans skipping 10,000 years of evolution).

ken
